html:
Etymology[edit]

From ēbrius (“drunk”) +‎ -ō (“denominative verb-forming suffix”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈeː.bri.oː/, [ˈeː.bɾi.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈe.bri.o/, [ˈɛː.bri.ɔ]

Verb[edit]

ēbriō (present infinitive ēbriāre, perfect active ēbriāvī, supine ēbriātum); first conjugation

  1. I make drunk, intoxicate

Derived terms[edit]

  • ēbriāmen
  • inēbriō

Related terms[edit]

  • ēbrius

Adjective[edit]

ēbriō

  1. dative masculine singular of ēbrius
  2. dative neuter singular of ēbrius
  3. ablative masculine singular of ēbrius
  4. ablative neuter singular of ēbrius

References[edit]

  • ebrio in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • ebrio in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
